description: From Middle English *plodden (found only in derivative plodder), probably originally a splash through water and mud, from plodde, pludde (“a puddle”) (whence modern plud). Compare Scots plod, plodge, plodder, dialectal Dutch plodden, plodderen, dialectal German ploddern, Danish pladder (“mire”).

entries.meaning: A slow or labored walk or other motion or activity.
examples: We started at a brisk walk and ended at a plod.

verbs.description: plod (third-person singular simple present plods, present participle plodding, simple past and past participle plodded)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To walk or move slowly and heavily or laboriously (+ on, through, over).

examples: Answ[er]. It may be, he was playing the Carpenter abrode for all their three livings, but sure it is, he was not idlely plodding the streetes, much lesse tipling in the Taverne with our idle swingers.

entries.meaning: To toil; to drudge; especially, to study laboriously and patiently.
examples: Poore plodding schoolemen, they are farre too low,
which by probations, rules and axiom’s goe,
He must be still familiar with the skyes,
which notes the reuolutions of thine eyes;

description: From Middle English plod. Cognate with Danish pladder (“mire”).

entries.meaning: (UK, mildly derogatory, uncountable, usually with "the") the police, police officers
(UK, mildly derogatory, countable) a police officer, especially a low-ranking one.
